Partnership.definition: an association of two or more persons or entities that conduct a business for profit as co-owners see also Uniform Partnership Act in the Important Laws section compare corporation

family partnership.definition: a partnership in which the partners are members of a family

general partnership.definition: a partnership in which each partner is liable for all partnership debts and obligations in full regardless of the amount of the individual partner's capital contribution comparein this entry

limited liability partnership.definition: a partnership formed under applicable state statute in which the partnership is liable as an entity for debts and obligations and the partners are not liable personally

lim·it·ed partnership.definition: a partnership in which the business is managed by one or more general partners and is provided with capital by limited partners who do not participate in management but who share in profits and whose individual liability is limited to the amount of their respective capital contributions comparein this entry

master limited partnership.definition: a limited partnership that offers interests for sale on the marketthe interests themselves sold as securities

min·ing partnership.definition: a partnership in which two or more persons jointly own a mining claim and actually engage in extracting minerals with the purpose of sharing profits and losses

non·trad·ing partnership.definition: a partnership that is not engaged in the buying and selling of goods called alsocomparein this entry

partnership at will.definition: a partnership whose duration is not fixed by contract and that is terminable at will by any partner

partnership by estoppel.definition: a partnership created by operation of law when a defendant by words or conduct represents himself or herself to the plaintiff or to the public as a partner and the plaintiff relies on the representation to his or her detriment

trad·ing partnership.definition: a partnership whose business involves the buying and selling of goods called alsocomparein this entry
